description:
We're all connected... There is the world around us, a world of people, tactile sensation, and culture. There is the wired world, inside the computer, of images, personalities, virtual experiences, and a culture all of its own. The day after a classmate commits suicide, Lain, a 14-year-old girl, discovers how closely the two worlds are linked when she receives an e-mail from the dead girl: I just abandoned my body. I still live here...

Has the line between the real world and the wired world begun to blur?

(Source: Geneon Entertainment)
synonyms: シリアルエクスペリメンツレイン

tags.name: Denpa
tags.description: Works that feature themes of social dissociation, delusions, and other issues like suicide, bullying, self-isolation, paranoia, and technological necessity in daily lives. Classic iconography: telephone poles, rooftops, and trains.

tags.name: Virtual World
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the world inside a video game.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Augmented Reality
tags.description: Prominently features events with augmented reality as the main setting.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Software Development
tags.description: Centers around characters developing or programming a piece of technology, software, gaming, etc.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: Video Games
tags.description: Centers around characters playing video games.

tags.name: Suicide
tags.description: The act or an instance of taking or attempting to take one's own life voluntarily and intentionally.

tags.name: Religion
tags.description: Centers on the belief that humanity is related to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Primarily Female Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of female characters.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Afterlife
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the afterlife.

tags.name: Adoption
tags.description: Features a character who has been adopted by someone who is neither of their biological parents.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: POV
tags.description: Point of View; features scenes shown from the perspective of the series protagonist.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Trains
tags.description: Prominently features trains.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Death Game
tags.description: Features characters participating in a game, where failure results in death.

tags.name: Age Gap
tags.description: Prominently features romantic relations between people with a significant age difference.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

tags.name: Zombie
tags.description: Prominently features reanimated corpses which often prey on live humans and turn them into zombies.

name.native: カール・ハウスホーファー

node.description:
Got his start in the industry as an animator at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) in the late '70s. Soon after he switched his focus from animating to directing and storyboarding works himself. As a director Nakamura is often praised for his use of sound, and is known for some of the most notable works of the medium such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Kino's Journey](https://anilist.co/anime/486/), and [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) among others.

Following several months of hospitalization, Nakamura passed away on June 29, 2013 due to pancreatic cancer. His death was announced nearly a month later.

__Notable works outside Anime:__

- Breath of Fire IV (Video Game, 2000) (OP Director)

[Website](http://www.konaka.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yamaki_nyx)

Chiaki J. Konaka is a Japanese writer and scenarist best known for shows such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Digimon Tamers](https://anilist.co/anime/874/) and [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/). He is also known to be the creator of Ultraman Gaia, as cited by Tsuburaya Productions.

Konaka's serious works generally have a dark, psychological tone. As a Cthulhu Mythos writer, he tends to add Lovecraftian elements to his works.

"Chiaki J. Konaka" is a very unusual name, as Japanese names typically do not include middle names. Konaka states that the "J." evokes the "Christian" name "John", due to him being born to parents who were members of the Anglican Church, but he does not identify as Christian. He began using the "J." at the age of 12, when he began making 8 mm films; he patterned the style after Western names such as "Charles M. Schulz".

He has cited [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) as his favorite screenwriting project.
Originating from [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) where he studied under [Atsuko Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/102141/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%B8%E7%94%B0%E9%9A%86%E5%AE%8F)

Takahiro Kishida is an animator and renown character designer.

Kishida's designs are well received by animators and attract talent into shows easily. He is also praised for his shot composition skills and copies of his layouts are widely distributed in the industry as drawing reference. Nowadays he is mostly only credited for character design in the shows he participates in, but in reality he works as an animation director uncredited quite often. He rarely heavily corrects the key animator's cuts, strongly believing that the animators' distinctiveness should be noticeable.

Noted for his designs on shows like [Haikyuu](https://anilist.co/anime/20464/), [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Madoka Magica](https://anilist.co/anime/9756/), [Baccano](https://anilist.co/anime/2251/) and more.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%B8%E7%94%B0%E9%9A%86%E5%AE%8F)

Takahiro Kishida is an animator and renown character designer.

Kishida's designs are well received by animators and attract talent into shows easily. He is also praised for his shot composition skills and copies of his layouts are widely distributed in the industry as drawing reference. Nowadays he is mostly only credited for character design in the shows he participates in, but in reality he works as an animation director uncredited quite often. He rarely heavily corrects the key animator's cuts, strongly believing that the animators' distinctiveness should be noticeable.

Noted for his designs on shows like [Haikyuu](https://anilist.co/anime/20464/), [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Madoka Magica](https://anilist.co/anime/9756/), [Baccano](https://anilist.co/anime/2251/) and more.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/31969571)

Originating from [Aubec](https://anilist.co/studio/6090/).

_Note: Not to be confused with the [other director](https://anilist.co/staff/242744/) by the same name._

[Website](https://jasminerodgers.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/jrodgersmusic) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/jasminerodgersofficial/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/c/jasminerodgers) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/jasminerodgersmusic)

Vocalist for [Boa](https://anilist.co/staff/159711/Boa). Daughter of British singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Paul Rodgers.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).
Occasional animator.

Affiliated with [Studio Silver](https://anilist.co/studio/6240/).

He is known for his sense of timing, which gives his animation often a stop-motion like feeling. He studied as an animator under [Atsuko Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/102141/), under whom he often worked on productions like [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/) or [You're Under Arrest](https://anilist.co/anime/1372/). He does also team up often with animator [Hirofumi Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101188/), who has influenced Matsutake's animation.

Aside of working on anime he has also worked on several games, mostly the Tales of series, where he served as animation supervisor on the animated sequences in most of the series' games.

Also close friends with [Atsushi Wakabayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105805/), [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/).

As a teenager Yamashita was influenced by the works of [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) and [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/), and was inspired to become an animator.

After graduating from Kurashiki Minami High School, he moved to Tokyo to become an animator and joined Bevore. After Bevore's dissolution, he joined Atelier Giga, and from there he joined Project Team Muu. There he was jointly in charge of the character designs, animation direction and storyboards for [Giant Robo the Animation: The Day the Earth Stood Still](https://anilist.co/anime/2321/). The production took nearly 10 years, during which Yamashita gave it his all. After the production was over he started losing his motivation for animation. Though, it sparked again, after having met [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/) on the opening animation for a video game called, Gensou Suikogaiden. 

In 2001, Yamashita worked as a key animator on [Spirited Away](https://anilist.co/anime/199/), a [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) feature film. There he was in charge of multiple scenes, most notably Chihiro and Haru's free fall at the end of the movie. This earned him high high praise from [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), and he was thus selected as one of the animation director's for [How's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/). Since then he has served as an animation director on most of Ghibli's movies.

In 2018, Yamashita directed "The Invisible Man," a short film part of the anthology collection [Modest Heroes](https://anilist.co/anime/103887/), produced by [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/). The film won the Newcomer's Award in the Animation Division at the 22nd Japan Media Arts Festival

Married to [Miho Shimogasa](https://anilist.co/staff/116279/).
_Note: Not to be confused with the [mangaka](https://anilist.co/staff/245226/Yuuichi-Tanaka)._
_Note: Not to be confused with the [mangaka](https://anilist.co/staff/245226/Yuuichi-Tanaka)._
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/insight001)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tak_tea3)

Animates on rare occasions.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1179422512028864512)

Currently he is a member of [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/), having formerly been a part of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) for over 18 years from 1996 to 2015. While he was still at Ghibli, he made his directorial debut as a 37-year-old with [The Secret World of Arrietty](https://anilist.co/anime/7711/), and became the youngest director of a theatrical feature produced by the studio. [Tomomi Mochizuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101821/), a director of a 1993 TV special, [Ocean Waves](https://anilist.co/anime/743/), is the youngest director of a Ghibli film at 34.

In 2015, Yonebayashi left with producer [Yoshiaki Nishimura](https://anilist.co/staff/121954/) and established Studio Ponoc. His first film at the new studio was [Mary and the Witch's Flower](https://anilist.co/anime/97981/).

Nominated for the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2015 for his second film, [When Marnie Was There](https://anilist.co/anime/20555/).
Affiliated with [GoHands](https://anilist.co/studio/309/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/真木太郎)

Tarou Maki is a producer. He graduated from the Department of Law at Waseda University in 1977 and joined Pioneer. In 1997 he founded production studio [Genco](https://anilist.co/studio/79/) and serves today still as its president.

Known for challenging camera angles and his ultramodern usage of CG backgrounds. Him and [Hirofumi Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101188/) are known as the "Golden Combo" together and their most notable works are [Neoranga](https://anilist.co/anime/1163/) and [Kaze no Youjinbou](https://anilist.co/anime/1145/). The duo were also often seen working on episodes in the [Naruto](https://anilist.co/anime/20/) series.

His pen-name Yasuaki Kurozu (黒津安明), comes from the names of [Akira Kurosawa (黒澤明)](https://anilist.co/staff/100099/) and Yasujirou Ozu (小津安二郎), two prominent Japanese film directors.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/213956842)

Affiliated with [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/28934362)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/新井浩一)

One of the founders of [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).
